title: Cloning Specific Directories with Git
description: When working on monorepo projects or analyzing open-source code, you might have experienced the inconvenience of bringing unnecessary source code i...

children.value: When working on monorepo projects or analyzing open-source code, you might have experienced the inconvenience of bringing unnecessary source code into your working directory, making the project heavy and consuming a lot of storage.
Git's sparse checkout feature allows you to easily resolve this issue by fetching only specific directories or files, excluding the rest.
Below is the URL and structure of the example project we'll be using for this exercise.

props.code:
.
├── README.md
├── scripts
│   └── empty.js
├── service1
│   ├── README.md
│   ├── scripts
│   │   └── empty.js
│   └── src
│       └── empty.js
└── service2
    ├── README.md
    ├── scripts
    │   └── empty.js
    └── src
        └── empty.js

children.value:
.
├── README.md
├── scripts
│   └── empty.js
├── service1
│   ├── README.md
│   ├── scripts
│   │   └── empty.js
│   └── src
│       └── empty.js
└── service2
    ├── README.md
    ├── scripts
    │   └── empty.js
    └── src
        └── empty.js
Sparse checkout has been available since Git v1.7.
Create and navigate to a directory to clone from the remote repository.
Add the desired file or directory path to sparse checkout targets. For this example, let's clone only the
directory located at the top level.
When specifying paths directly in files, the presence or absence of a leading slash (
) can significantly affect the result. If you omit the leading slash, Git will clone all directories or files named

props.code:
git remote add origin https://github.com/besfir/example-partial-clone
git pull origin main

children.value: Verify that the operation completed successfully.
Starting from Git v2.25, sparse checkout can be more conveniently achieved using the API.
Initialize a local repository by fetching
Initialize sparse checkout feature. Starting from v2.35, the
Check out to the desired branch, and sparse checkout will be applied.
Verify that the operation completed successfully.
Upon examination, it's noted that along with the specified
directory, files at the top level were also cloned. This is because it operated in cone mode.
When using the Sparse checkout API, you have the option to choose between cone mode and non-cone mode for selecting targets.
Previously, it could only be selected when initializing, but starting with Git v.2.35, the
command could be omitted, allowing it to be used with the

props.code:
git sparse-checkout set service2/scripts --cone
# or
git sparse-checkout set service2/scripts

In contrast to cone mode, this mode allows you to select
only the specified files or directories
, regardless of the directory hierarchy. It produces the same result as when manually performed.

        └── empty.js

title: How to Use and Customize Tailwind CSS Typography Plugin
description: When developing a website that needs to display lengthy content, such as markdown-rendered text or HTML fetched from a CMS, considerable effort is...

children.value:
When developing a website that needs to display lengthy content, such as markdown-rendered text or HTML fetched from a CMS, considerable effort is required to make the text look beautiful and readable.
The Tailwind CSS typography plugin makes it very easy and quick to apply typography to your content.
Typography refers to the technique or art of making text look beautiful and readable by combining elements such as fonts, text sizes, line spacing, and margins.
Since Tailwind CSS installation is recommended differently for each environment, it is replaced with the

.
Here's how to install the plugin.
You can apply typography to the elements you want by combining the

props.code:
What is Lorem Ipsum?

Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing and typesetting industry.

Lorem Ipsum has been the industry's standard dummy text ever since the 1500s, when an unknown printer took a galley of type and scrambled it to make a type specimen book.

children.value: Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing and typesetting industry.
Lorem Ipsum has been the industry's standard dummy text ever since the 1500s, when an unknown printer took a galley of type and scrambled it to make a type specimen book.
When applying typography, the maximum width is limited to

to maintain readability of the content.
However, in production environments,  there are often many cases where you want to utilize all available width. In this case, you can use the
class to override the maximum width.

props.code: {{ markdown }}

children.value: The typography plugin allows you to specify styles by combining four types of modifiers:
: for adjusting typography size-related styles such as font size, line height, and margins.
: for handling gray-scale colors that goes well with text colors.
: for applying styles to specific HTML elements.
: for applying color inversion to text for dark mode.
Modifier classes are designed to be used with the multi-class modifier pattern and must be used in conjunction with the base
A design pattern that allows you to apply styles to elements by combining multiple classes. This pattern enables more flexible styling than using a single class.
When adjusting typography size-related styles, such as font size, line height, and margins, you can use size modifiers.
To illustrate, let's create an example based on hypothetical requirements:
font size for devices with a resolution below
font size for devices with a resolution of
is the default modifier, so it can be omitted.
The typography plugin comes with five pre-defined gray scale modifier classes suitable for body text.
Monotone refers to a combination of colors consisting of a single hue (gray, black, or white), while gray scale refers to a combination of colors consisting of various shades of gray.
Again, let's create an example based on hypothetical requirements:
Apply the slate color scheme as the default.
Apply the stone color scheme for devices with a resolution of
You can also use all the color modifiers provided by Tailwind CSS, but they are limited to link elements.
element on devices with a resolution below
element on devices with a resolution of
Element modifiers allow you to apply styles to individual HTML elements. Here's a list of supported element modifiers:
To illustrate, let's create an example based on hypothetical requirements:

props.code:
<article class="prose prose-h2:underline prose-h3:underline prose-img:rounded-lg prose-a:text-sky-500">
  {{ markdown }}
</article>

children.value: All colors in the typography plugin include a dark mode version. You can activate this by using the
Although you can achieve a high level of typography sophistication with the basic usage, what if:
You want to exclude typography styles from specific elements and use Tailwind CSS default styles.
You need customization because modifiers alone are insufficient to achieve the desired style.

class make element as  sandbox, isolating it from the influence of typography styles.
And, it's important to note that even if the
class is applied to elements within the
class, typography styles will not be applied.

props.code:
What is Lorem Ipsum?

Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing and typesetting industry.

Lorem Ipsum has been the industry's standard dummy text ever since the 1500s, when an unknown printer took a galley of type and scrambled it to make a type specimen book.

Lorem Ipsum has been the industry's standard dummy text ever since the 1500s, when an unknown printer took a galley of type and scrambled it to make a type specimen book.
element acts as a sandbox, preventing typography styles from being applied to self and any of its internal elements.
element also won't have typography styles applied for the reasons mentioned earlier.

The property keys written in the example match the modifiers we've learned earlier.
Therefore, to customize the elements you want, you can redefine them reference the browser's developer tools and the
style definition code of the typography plugin

props.code:
/** @type {import('tailwindcss').Config} */
module.exports = {
  theme: {
    extend: {
      typography: (theme) => ({
        DEFAULT: {},
        sm: {},
        base: {},
        lg: {},
        xl: {},
        '2xl': {},
        slate: {},
        gray: {},
        zinc: {},
        neutral: {},
        stone: {},
        red: {},
        orange: {},
        amber: {},
        yellow: {},
        lime: {},
        green: {},
        emerald: {},
        teal: {},
        cyan: {},
        sky: {},
        blue: {},
        indigo: {},
        violet: {},
        purple: {},
        fuchsia: {},
        pink: {},
        rose: {},
        invert: {},
      }),
    },
  },
  plugins: [
    require('@tailwindcss/typography'),
    // ...
  ],
}

children.value: Let's create an example based on hypothetical requirements:
Currently, the table element occupies the entire available width with
. We want to change this to use only the width of the content by setting it to
We want to standardize the font weight of h1, h2, h3, and h4 elements to
to prevent header overlap when navigating with internal links.
We'll change the default typography font color to black and to white in dark mode.

Adding a new modifier is the same process as overriding existing modifiers, with the difference being that you add the modifier not built into the plugin as a property key.
Let's add a modifier called
, which handles colors, as an example.
In the previous example, we only utilized CSS variables built into the plugin to compose styles, so there was no need to input additional values for the

property.
This time, let's add a new property that is not built into the plugin.
When adding a new CSS variable like this, it must be added in the inversion modifier.
When using the created brand modifier, it should be used as

title: Configuring Timezone in Alpine Linux: Handling in Local Environment and Docker Images
description: In a production environment, a time zone must be manually set up for reasons such as cron job, log time localization, and time synchronization betw...

children.value:
In a production environment, there are times when you need to set the time zone yourself for reasons such as cron work, log time localization, and time synchronization between DB and OS.
The time zone setting method differs depending on the linux distribution. In this article, we will learn how to set the time zone in Alpine Linux, one of the lightweight Linux distributions, and how to optimize and apply it when setting in a Docker environment.
Time zone settings in local environment
First, let's look at how to set it up in a local environment by installing it directly on your computer.
Since Alpine Linux does not include packages related to time zone settings, install the
Check whether the package was installed properly using the

command.
This command displays information about the actual file or directory pointed to by the symbolic link.

props.code:
Africa             CST6CDT            Etc                Greenwich          Kwajalein          PRC                UCT                posixrules       
America            Canada             Europe             HST                Libya              PST8PDT            US                 right
Antarctica         Chile              Factory            Hongkong           MET                Pacific            UTC                zone.tab
Arctic             Cuba               GB                 Iceland            MST                Poland             Universal          zone1970.tab
Asia               EET                GB-Eire            Indian             MST7MDT            Portugal           W-SU
Atlantic           EST                GMT                Iran               Mexico             ROC                WET
Australia          EST5EDT            GMT+0              Israel             NZ                 ROK                Zulu
Brazil             Egypt              GMT-0              Jamaica            NZ-CHAT            Singapore          iso3166.tab
CET                Eire               GMT0               Japan              Navajo             Turkey             leap-seconds.list

children.value:
Africa             CST6CDT            Etc                Greenwich          Kwajalein          PRC                UCT                posixrules       
America            Canada             Europe             HST                Libya              PST8PDT            US                 right
Antarctica         Chile              Factory            Hongkong           MET                Pacific            UTC                zone.tab
Arctic             Cuba               GB                 Iceland            MST                Poland             Universal          zone1970.tab
Asia               EET                GB-Eire            Indian             MST7MDT            Portugal           W-SU
Atlantic           EST                GMT                Iran               Mexico             ROC                WET
Australia          EST5EDT            GMT+0              Israel             NZ                 ROK                Zulu
Brazil             Egypt              GMT-0              Jamaica            NZ-CHAT            Singapore          iso3166.tab
CET                Eire               GMT0               Japan              Navajo             Turkey             leap-seconds.list
Set a symbolic link to the desired time zone in the localtime file.
Since I will set the time zone to Korean time, I will set a symbolic link to the

file.
The target path of the symbolic link is
(Optional) Specify a timezone explicitly in the timezone file.
Although the time zone set in
is not reflected, it is recommended to specify it for explicit use.
Time zone settings in Docker environment

When setting up the Alpine Linux time zone in a Docker environment, simply write each step described above in a Docker file.
You can optimize time zone settings in the Docker environment through single-stage build and multi-stage build that can be selected depending on the project environment.

Single-stage builds are used in simple environments and build the image by performing each step sequentially.
Here's how to build a Docker image using a single stage build.

props.code:
FROM node:18.16.0-alpine3.17  

RUN apk add --no-cache tzdata && \
    cp /usr/share/zoneinfo/Asia/Seoul /etc/localtime && \
    echo "Asia/Seoul" > /etc/timezone && \
    apk del tzdata

children.value: flag is used, which is used to make the image lighter by not storing a cache when installing a package.
Line 4: Since we will delete the
package, copy it without setting a symbolic link.
Line 6: Lighten the image by deleting the
package that is no longer needed.
This function is supported starting from Docker v17.06, and is a function that divides the Docker image into stages to
easily exclude elements that are necessary in the building process but not necessary in the final result.

Multi-stage builds have strengths in complex environments, dividing the build process into multiple stages to include only the files needed in the final image.
Here's how to build a Docker image using a multi-stage build.

props.code:
FROM node:18.16.0-alpine3.17 AS base

# Builder process
FROM base AS builder

RUN apk add tzdata

# Runner process
FROM base AS runner

COPY --from=builder /usr/share/zoneinfo/Asia/Seoul /etc/localtime
RUN echo "Asia/Seoul" > /etc/timezone
